text.p: Aasche Transportation Services Inc said its 1996 results were hurt by several non-recurring one-time charges that totaled $1.9 million after taxes or $0.48 per share.
For the full year, it posted a loss of $0.67 per share compared to a 1995 loss of $0.34 per share.
The charge related to a writedown of Polar Express equipment, a Polar restructuring charge and a Polar litigation settlement.
"In addition, we wrote down the value of our equipment to better reflect the current used equipment market," said chief financial officer Leon Monachos in a statement.

"We believe these writedowns should be sufficient to avoid any additional equipment writedowns in 1997," he added. "We further believe we have taken the last of our non-operating writedowns associated with the Polar Express acquisition," he said.

In a direct effort to address driver shortage problems, operating inefficiencies, asset utilization concerns and equipment debt issues that have plagued Polar Express over the course of 1996, the company entered into a purchase agreement to sell 68 Polar tractors and 141 Polar trailers for $4.6 million. The transaction is expected to generate $1.4 million in net cash proceeds to the company with no significant earnings effect expected in 1997.
Although the loss from the sale in connection with the writedown of Polar equipment to net realizable value was recorded in 1996, the transaction was completed on March 25, 1997.
For the year, Aasche posted a loss of $0.67 per share.
